Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biomimetic Self-assembly of Polymer-inorganic Hybrid Nanocompartments with Biomedical Delivery Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Innovative functional hybrid nanomaterials may offer a new generation of highly selective and effective therapeutics and diagnostics for human health. The goal of this award is to synthesize a new class of polymer-inorganic vesicular hybrids for drug delivery through polymer-assisted nanoparticle self-assembly. These functional vesicular hybrids mimic viral capsids from the aspects of size, surface patch, surface topology, and mechanical properties, thus facilitating their functions in medical delivery. Each building block of polymer-tethered nanoparticles in the assemblies serves as a polymeric brick to uniquely define the local physical and chemical cues on the membrane surface of vesicular hybrids at the nanoscale. This strategy enables the preparation of vesicular hybrids with critical features required by biomedical delivery, including (1) tailored permeability, surface functionality, surface topology, and mechanical properties, (2) tunable inherent or new synergetic properties of inorganic components due to significantly enhanced ordering and weight fraction of inorganic nanoparticles in the assemblies, (3) remote-controlled release of encapsulated cargo in addition to imaging and manipulation capability while preserving the original unique functionalities of the polymer ligands. The objectives of this proposal are: (1) to understand and control the construction of vesicular hybrids with well-defined tunable surface patches, surface topology, and mechanical properties at the nanoscale; (2) to design multicompartment vesicular hybrids and systems that respond to external stimuli including pH, temperature, light, and potentially electromagnetic field; (3) to explore the encapsulation of drug compounds in vesicular hybrids and study the kinetics of remote-controlled release of cargo.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymer-inorganic hybrid nanocompartments with highly organized, topologically complex surfaces have important applications ranging from healthcare and medicine (e.g., imaging contrast agents and drug delivery vesicles) to optoelectronics. The proposed program will develop new robust multifunctional hybrid compartments to address current challenges in biomedical delivery, explore a new class of remote-controlled responsive materials, and provide new insights into polymer-assisted self-assembly of inorganic nanoparticles. This award will allow the PI to integrate interdisciplinary research on biomimetic polymer-inorganic hybrids with education of students at the graduate, undergraduate, and high-school levels. The goal is to give students a competitive edge in both academia and industry, and to help them become leaders in these new and emerging research fields. The proposed outreach program seeks to: i) incorporate current advances in emerging research fields into curriculum development such as laboratory design at both graduate and undergraduate levels, ii) recruit and train students particularly under-represented groups at both graduate and undergraduate levels, iii) create a mentoring program aimed at interested high school students, and iv) bring advanced educational science demonstrations to classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vesicles consisting of liquids (e.g., water) enclosed by a thin membrane of lipids or polymers are attractive as drug delivery vehicles for efficient therapeutics and diagnostics of diseases and have made the greatest clinical impact. These organic materials are in stark contrast to inorganic nanoscale particles that often exhibit intrinsic optical, electronic and magnetic properties. Despite reasonable efforts over the past decades, there remain challenges in effectively integrating nanoparticles into vesicular membranes in order to achieve new or advanced properties of the materials. The NSF project entitled, “CAREER: Biomimetic Self-assembly of Polymer-inorganic Hybrid Nanocompartments with Biomedical Delivery Applications,” aims to synthesize a new class of polymer-inorganic vesicular hybrids for drug delivery through polymer-assisted nanoparticle self-assembly. Herein specific objectives include (i) Construction of vesicular hybrids with well-defined chemical patches, surface topology, and mechanical properties; (ii) Design of multicompartment vesicular hybrids and systems that respond to external stimuli; (iii) Encapsulation and controlled release of drug compounds in (or from) vesicular hybrids.

     In the five-year period of this project, we have successfully accomplished our project objectives. We first demonstrated the concept of utilizing the shape and dimension of nanoparticle building blocks to control the physical and chemical traits of hybrid vesicles containing monolayer of polymer-modified nanoparticles. Our results showed that the chemical patches, surface topology and mechanical properties of hybrid vesicles can be tailored by varying the size of nanoparticles and the length and chemistry of polymer ligands. We further studied the fabrication of complex hybrid vesicles with different morphologies using the lateral phase-separation of polymer-modified nanoparticles confined in the vesicular membrane. A variety of hybrid vesicles containing multiple types of building blocks were produced by using this method. As a result, the physical (e.g., optical and magnetic response) and chemical properties of hybrid vesicles can be precisely controlled, thus fascinating the performance of such vesicles in biological imaging and therapy. Moreover, we evaluated the encapsulation of therapeutic compounds in hybrid vesicles and externally controlled release of payload from the vesicles. Our results indicate that the release of payload can be modulated externally by near-infrared light and alternating magnetic field.    

     The project has supported seven PhD students (including, three minority students and three female students) and one Master student for certain period of time or throughout his/her whole period of graduate study. Students involved in this project have received a number of prestigious awards such as NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. By now, six students have successfully received their PhD or MS degrees, while two students are working towards their PhD graduation. Among students graduated, two PhDs and one MSs are working as Research Scientist or Engineer in industrial. Two PhDs, who aim to find a faculty position, are working as Postdoctoral Fellow at National Institute of Health. Moreover, the project has also provided research opportunities for seven local high school students (including four economically disadvantaged high school students selected through ACS SEED program) and twelve undergraduate students. The research program has led to fifteen research articles published on scientific journals. These scientific results have been also shared on international meetings including on the 2013 International Polymer Colloid Group Research Conference, the 246th, 249th, 253th and 254th American Chemical Society National Meeting, the 2016 Materials Research Society Fall Meeting, the 7th International Conference for Colloids and Interfaces, the 2016 Nano Korea Symposium, the 2017 Mid-Atlantic Micro/Nano Alliance Symposium, the 2017 Korea-China Bilateral Symposium on Polymer Materials, the 2017 Chinese American Society of Nanomedicine and Nanobiotechnology Annual Meeting, and the 2018 American Society for Photobiology Meeting.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2018
Modified by: Zhihong Nie
